author: jpsnover
body:
If a module has bad verbs, and you specify:
$PSDefaultParameterValues."Import-module:DisableNameCheck"=$true

You can import that module and not receive any warnings.  HOWEVER
If that module has a nested module which has bad verbs, then it will complain about those verbs when you import the original module.
 
In other words, NestedModule processing does not respect $PSDefaultParameterValues.
This turns out to be a big headache as there are a number of 3rd party modules we are using with bad names and the warnings are screwing up the signal-to-noise ratio of our logs.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
Isn't this part of the design of `$PSDefaultParameterValues`?

A default set in global scope is not supposed to affect a module - and nested modules are processed in the scope of the module, not in global scope.

If the nested modules won't fix their names - isn't it the responsibility of the module depending on the nested modules to disable the name check?  This would require explicitly import the modules in a psm1 instead of using the `NestedModules` property in a psd1, but it seems like this would be consistent with the design for safely setting default parameter values.

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as by-design and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

title: NestedModule processing does not respect $PSDefaultParameterValues
